title: Requires office of alcoholism and substance abuse services to establish a curriculum for course of instruction on adolescent problem gambling in grades 4 through 12
summary: Requires the office of alcoholism and substance abuse services, in consultation with an adolescent gambling task force, to establish a course of instruction on adolescent problem gambling which may be provided in grades 4 through 12.

       AN ACT to amend the mental hygiene law, in  relation  to  requiring  the
         office  of  alcoholism  and  substance  abuse  services to establish a
         curriculum in problem gambling which may be provided  in  grades  four
         through  twelve;  to  establish  an adolescent gambling task force and
         providing for its duties; and providing  for  the  repeal  of  certain
         provisions upon expiration thereof

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Section 19.07 of the  mental  hygiene  law  is  amended  by
    2  adding a new subdivision (i) to read as follows:
    3    (I) THE OFFICE OF ALCOHOLISM AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE SERVICES SHALL ESTAB-
    4  LISH  A  CURRICULUM  FOR  A  COURSE OF INSTRUCTION IN ADOLESCENT PROBLEM
    5  GAMBLING WHICH MAY, AT THE OPTION OF ANY SCHOOL, BE PROVIDED  IN  GRADES
    6  FOUR  THROUGH TWELVE. SUCH COURSE OF INSTRUCTION SHALL INCLUDE MATERIALS
    7  TO EDUCATE STUDENTS ON THE DANGERS AND CONSEQUENCES OF PROBLEM GAMBLING,
    8  AND SHALL BE AVAILABLE ON THE INTERNET WEBSITE OF SUCH OFFICE.
    9    S 2. Adolescent gambling task force. (a) An adolescent  gambling  task
   10  force  is  hereby  created to examine, evaluate and make recommendations
   11  concerning the content and manner  of  instruction  for  the  course  of
   12  instruction  in  problem  gambling  established  by  subdivision  (i) of
   13  section 19.07 of the mental hygiene law, as added by section one of this
   14  act. Such task force shall also examine the prevalence and  consequences
   15  of problem gambling among adolescents.
   16    (b)  The  adolescent  gambling  task  force  shall be composed of nine
   17  members as follows: the commissioner of alcoholism and  substance  abuse
   18  services,  one  member appointed by the commissioner of health to repre-
   19  sent the department of health, one member appointed by the  commissioner

    1  of  education  to  represent  the  department  of education, two members
    2  appointed by the temporary president of the senate to  represent  organ-
    3  izations  which  serve or advocate on behalf of adolescents, two members
    4  appointed  by  the  speaker  of  the assembly to represent organizations
    5  which serve or advocate on behalf of adolescents, one  member  appointed
    6  by  the  minority  leader  of the senate and one person appointed by the
    7  minority leader of the assembly. The appointees shall be broadly  repre-
    8  sentative  of  the geographic areas of the state, and shall serve at the
    9  pleasure of the appointing official for such member. The  chair  of  the
   10  task  force  shall be the commissioner of alcoholism and substance abuse
   11  services.  The commissioner of alcoholism and substance  abuse  services
   12  shall,  on  or  before  January  1, 2012, report to the governor and the
   13  legislature as to whether all  members  of  the  task  force  have  been
   14  appointed,  and if not, which member or members have not been appointed.
   15  Vacancies in the membership of the task force shall  be  filled  in  the
   16  manner provided for original appointments.
   17    (c)  The  task force may meet within and without the state, shall hold
   18  public hearings, and shall have all the powers of a legislative  commit-
   19  tee pursuant to the legislative law.
   20    (d)  The  members  of the task force shall receive no compensation for
   21  their services, but shall be allowed their actual and necessary expenses
   22  incurred in the performance of their duties pursuant to this section.
   23    (e) To the maximum extent feasible, the task force shall  be  entitled
   24  to  request  and  receive,  and  shall utilize and be provided with such
   25  facilities, resources and  data  of  any  court,  department,  division,
   26  board, bureau, commission or agency of the state or any political subdi-
   27  vision  thereof  as  it may reasonably request to properly carry out its
   28  powers and duties pursuant to this section.
   29    (f) On or before June 1, 2012, the task  force  shall  report  to  the
   30  office  of alcoholism and substance abuse services its findings, conclu-
   31  sions and recommendations on implementing the provisions of  subdivision
   32  (i)  of section 19.07 of the mental hygiene law, as added by section one
   33  of this act.
   34    (g) On or before June 1, 2013, the task  force  shall  report  to  the
   35  office  of  alcoholism and substance abuse services on the status of and
   36  any actions taken on the recommendations made  pursuant  to  subdivision
   37  (f) of this section.
   38    S  3.  This act shall take effect immediately, except that section one
   39  of this act shall take effect September 1, 2012, and section two of this
   40  act shall expire and be deemed repealed June 2, 2013.
